Key Arguments: The bill is undemocratic and a threat to free speech.
It grants excessive control to the government over what can be said, moving truth determination from the people to bureaucrats.
The bill undermines the principle of subsidiarity, which suggests larger social structures should support smaller ones in decision-making.
It could suppress both lies and truths, preventing necessary public discourse.
There are no checks and balances in the bill to prevent misuse of power.
